question: what is parkinesonism?
answers: you spelt it wrong ! Parkinson's disease is one of the most common neurologic disorders of the elderly. The term "parkinsonism" refers to any condition that causes any combination of the types of movement abnormalities seen in Parkinson's disease by damaging or destroying dopamine neurons in a certain area of the brain.

Parkinsonism describes the common symptoms of Parkinson's disease - tremor, rigidity, akinesia or bradykinesia and postural instability. Those patients who respond to drug treatment for Parkinson's disease are diagnosed with it, and those who do not have parkinsonism.
labelled_summary: Parkinson's disease is a prevalent neurologic disorder among the elderly. The term "parkinsonism" encompasses any condition leading to movement abnormalities similar to those observed in Parkinson's disease. This condition arises from the damage or destruction of dopamine neurons in a specific brain region. Common symptoms of parkinsonism include tremors, rigidity, akinesia or bradykinesia, and postural instability. Diagnosis of Parkinson's disease is established in patients responding to drug treatments, while those who do not respond are categorized under parkinsonism.

question: what does m.c.h.c stand for in my hematology test? I wont be able to see my dr. for another week and it bother
answers: Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration "This test measures the average concentration of hemoglobin in red blood cells."
Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration Usually used to determine anemia.

MCHC (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration) Hemoglobin x 100 Hematocrit This test measures the average concentration of hemoglobin in red blood cells. It is most valuable in evaluating therapy for anaemia because Hemoglobin and Hematocrit are used, not R.B.C. in the calculation. Low MCHC means that a unit of packed R.B.C.’s contain less hemoglobin than normal and a high MCHC means that there is more hemoglobin in a unit of R.B.C.’s. Increased MCHC is seen in spherocytosis, and not seen in pernicious anaemia whereas decreased levels may indicate iron deficiency, blood loss, B6 deficiency of thalassemia. Normal Adult Range: 32 - 36 % Optimal Adult Reading: 34 Higher ranges are found in newborns and infants
Mean corpuscular hemoblobin level.... send me your other results in CBC and I will post my opinion... flightphysician@hotmail.com
m.c.h.c stands for "corpuscular heomoglobin concentration".
labelled_summary: For information purposes, the Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) test measures the average concentration of hemoglobin in red blood cells and is commonly used to assess anemia. The formula for MCHC is Hemoglobin x 100 divided by Hematocrit. This test is particularly useful in evaluating therapy for anemia, using Hemoglobin and Hematocrit in the calculation instead of R.B.C. A low MCHC indicates that a unit of packed R.B.C.'s contains less hemoglobin than normal, while a high MCHC suggests more hemoglobin in a unit of R.B.C.'s. Increased MCHC is observed in conditions like spherocytosis but not in pernicious anemia. Decreased levels may indicate iron deficiency, blood loss, B6 deficiency, or thalassemia. The normal adult range for MCHC is 32-36%, with an optimal reading of 34%. Higher ranges are found in newborns and infants. MCHC is an essential parameter in assessing and managing anemia.

question: What is the main cause of Nephrotic Syndrome?
answers: Nephrotic syndrom is the end result of a variety of diseases that damage the capillaries of the glomerulus (the place where urine formation begins.) Factors causing NS include any disorder that may affect the glomerulus, including immunologic disorders, toxic injury to the kidneys, neoplasms, metabolic abnormalities, infections, and diseases of the vascular system. Causes are classified according to the changes found in the capillaries of the glomerulus when examined by electron microscopy. Clinically, NS leads to the loss of a large amount of protein in the urine, which in turn leads to edema (fluid retention). Adrenal cortical steroids have a dramatic immediate effect on the condition but their use does not alter the survival rate.

Many conditions and diseases can cause nephrotic syndrome, including: Diabetes and lupus. Diabetes is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults in the United States. 2 Infections, such as HIV, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C. Cancer, such as breast cancer, lung cancer, and Hodgkin's lymphoma. Medications, including certain anti-inflammatory drugs such as aspirin and ibuprofen. Illegal drugs, such as heroin. Conditions such as preeclampsia, a pregnancy-related condition; graft rejection following an organ transplant; and allergic reactions to bee stings. Unknown factors.
labelled_summary: Nephrotic syndrome (NS) is a condition resulting from various diseases that damage the glomerulus capillaries, where urine formation begins. Causes include immunologic disorders, toxic kidney injury, neoplasms, metabolic abnormalities, infections, and vascular system diseases. NS leads to significant protein loss in urine, causing fluid retention and edema. Common triggers encompass diabetes, lupus, infections (HIV, hepatitis B, hepatitis C), cancers (breast, lung, Hodgkin's lymphoma), medications (aspirin, ibuprofen), illegal drugs (heroin), and conditions like preeclampsia and graft rejection post-transplant. Steroids provide immediate relief but don't affect survival rates. The syndrome can also occur without clear causes.

question: how can i tell if im going through menopause?
answers: Perimenopause (and later, menopause itself) is not an illness, but a natural process in a woman’s body. Your symptoms, like night sweats, irregular periods, vaginal dryness, and menopause insomnia, are just indicators of underlying hormonal imbalances or metabolic damage from poor nutrition, stress and other factors. Menopause: * Irregular periods. Your menstrual periods may stop suddenly, or gradually get lighter or heavier and then stop. The unpredictability of your periods may be your first clue that menopause is approaching. * Decreased fertility. When ovulation begins to fluctuate, you're less likely to become pregnant. Until yoyou haven't had a period for a year, however, pregnancy is still possible. * Vaginal and urinary changes. As your estrogen level declines, the tissues lining your vagina and urethra — the opening to your bladder — become drier, thinner and less elastic. With decreased lubrication yoyou may experience burning or itching, along with increased risk of infections of your urinary tract or vagina. These changes may make sexual intercourse uncomfortable or even painful. Yoyou may feel the need to urinate more frequently or more urgently, and yoyou may experience urinary incontinence. * Hot flashes. As your estrogen level drops, your blood vessels may expand rapidly, causing your skin temperature to rise. This can lead to a feeling of warmth that moves upward from your chest to your shoulders, neck and head. Yoyou may sweat, and as the sweat evaporates from your skin, yoyou may feel chilled, weak and slightly faint. Your face might look flushed, and red blotches may appear on your chest, neck and arms. Most hot flashes last from 30 seconds to several minutes, although they can last much longer. The frequency, as well as the duration, of hot flashes varies from person to person. Yoyou may have them once every hour or only occasionally. They can occur any time during the day or night. They may be a part of your life for a year or more, or yoyou may never have them. * Sleep disturbances and night sweats. Night sweats are often a consequence of hot flashes. Yoyou may awaken from a sound sleep with soaking night sweats followed by chills. Yoyou may have difficulty falling back to sleep or achieving a deep, restful sleep. Lack of sleep may affect your mood and overall health. * Changes in appearance. Many women gain a modest amount of weight — about 5 pounds on average — during the menopausal transition. The fat that once was concentrated in your hips and thighs may settle above your waist and in your abdomen. Yoyou may notice a loss of fullness in your breasts, thinning hair and wrinkles in your skin. If yoyou previously experienced adult acne, it may become worse. Although your estrogen level drops, your body continues to produce small amounts of the male hormone testosterone. As a result, yoyou may develop coarse hair on your chin, upper lip, chest and abdomen. * Emotional and cognitive changes. Yoyou may experience irritability, fatigue, decreased memory and diminished concentration as yoyou approach menopause. These symptoms have sometimes been attributed to hormonal fluctuations. Yet other factors are more likely to contribute to these changes, including sleep deprivation and stressful life events — such as the illness or death of a parent, grown children leaving home or returning home, and retirement.
all the men stop and stare at you
labelled_summary: Perimenopause and menopause are natural processes in a woman's body, not illnesses, signaling hormonal imbalances or metabolic changes influenced by factors like poor nutrition and stress. Menopause symptoms include irregular periods, decreased fertility, vaginal and urinary changes, hot flashes, night sweats, and sleep disturbances. Vaginal dryness, thinning tissues, and decreased lubrication may lead to discomfort during intercourse. Changes in appearance, emotional shifts, and cognitive changes, such as irritability and decreased memory, are also associated with menopause. While weight gain is common, particularly around the abdomen, emotional and cognitive changes can be influenced by factors beyond hormonal fluctuations, including sleep deprivation and life events like parental illness or retirement. Understanding menopausal symptoms can help women navigate this natural life stage.

question: can yoyou take both family medical leave act and sdi for maternity leave? If so how long is the leave for each?
answers: Check with your human resources department but i believe that the total allowable leave time is 12 weeks. That is SDI time and FMLA time put together.

The federal Family Medical Leave Act requires employers with at least 50 employees to provide up to 12 weeks of leave to care for a newborn child. It does not require any of this leave to be paid, but requires that yoyou be reinstated to the same, or equivalent job when yoyou return. If the company offers various paid benefits (sick time, short-term disability), that time is taken concurrently with the FMLA leave. Some states also have family medical leave acts which may provide more generous benefits. Your human resources department should be able to provide yoyou with helpful information.
labelled_summary: Yoyou can combine the Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA) and State Disability Insurance (SDI) for maternity leave. FMLA, a federal law, grants up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave to care for a newborn child, with job protection upon return. If your company offers paid benefits like sick time or short-term disability, these can run concurrently with FMLA. However, FMLA itself does not guarantee paid leave. Some states may have their own family medical leave laws, offering more generous benefits. For specific details, contact your HR department.

question: What is the disease labled nph?
answers: Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) is a neurological condition which normally occurs in adults 55-years and older. NPH is an accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) causing the ventricles of the brain to enlarge, and in turn, stretching the nerve tissue of the brain causing a triad of symptoms: gait disturbance, dementia and urinary incontinence.
NORMAL PRESSURE HYDROCEPHALUS more info here....
labelled_summary: Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) is a neurological condition that typically manifests in adults aged 55 and older. It involves the abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), leading to the enlargement of the brain's ventricles. This enlargement, in turn, causes stretching of the nerve tissue in the brain, resulting in a triad of symptoms: gait disturbance, dementia, and urinary incontinence.

question: what is "assisted reproduction"?
answers: Reproductive technology is a term for all current and anticipated uses of technology in human and animal reproduction, including: * artificial insemination * artificial wombs * cloning (see human cloning for the special case of human beings) * cryopreservation of sperm, oocytes, embryos * embryo testing * embryo transfer * genetic engineering * hormone treatment to increase fertility * in vitro fertilization o intracytoplasmic sperm injection * preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD) * sperm selection * reprogenetics

It is any form of reproduction where there is a medical procedure involved. It ranges from the use of drugs to promote ovulation, to the invitro fertilization of an egg, and its later implantation in the woman's uterus.
labelled_summary: Reproductive technology encompasses a broad spectrum of current and anticipated technological applications in both human and animal reproduction. This includes practices such as artificial insemination, the use of artificial wombs, cloning (with a specific focus on human cloning), cryopreservation of reproductive materials like sperm, oocytes, and embryos, embryo testing, embryo transfer, genetic engineering, hormone treatments to enhance fertility, in vitro fertilization (including intracytoplasmic sperm injection), preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD), and sperm selection. Collectively, these technologies represent various medical procedures involved in reproduction, ranging from the administration of fertility-promoting drugs to the in vitro fertilization of an egg, followed by the implantation of the embryo into the woman's uterus. This comprehensive field is often referred to as reprogenetics.

question: How does blood PH affect our health?
answers: Your blood pH effects everything that goes on inside your body. Human blood stays in a very narrow pH range right around 7.3. If your pH is below or above this range yoyou can suffer symptoms and/or disease. For example, when the pH is too acidic or alkaline enzymes that are normal constructive can become destructive. Yoyou can maintain a healthy pH by doing all the good things yoyou hear about--eat right, take your vitamins, and exercise.

labelled_summary: For information purposes, the blood pH, which typically stays within a narrow range around 7.3, significantly influences bodily functions. Deviating from this range, either towards acidity or alkalinity, can lead to symptoms and diseases. An imbalanced pH may turn normally constructive enzymes into destructive agents. Maintaining a healthy pH is achievable through practices such as a balanced diet, vitamin supplementation, and regular exercise.

question: I was thinking about joining a health club. Or just exercise at home doing Taebo. What do yoyou think is better?
answers: Studies have found that people who exercise at home are more likely to stick with it because it is more convenient. It is also much less expensive. Yoyou should do more than one type of exercise. The components of physical fitness are: Aerobic Endurance: The most important because it has the largest effect on the biggest killer, cardiovascular disease. Walking, swimming, cycling, etc. are good aerobic exercises. Muscular Endurance and Muscular Strength: Along with maintaining the proper weight, this is what makes yoyou look buff! Resistance training is the way to get these. Barbells or dumbells that cost $100 or less are just as good as exercise machines that cost thousands. Flexibility: Keeps yoyou from getting sprains and torn muscles. Yoga is the king, but there are a lot of effective stretching exercises. Body Fat Composition: Maintaining proper body weight helps prevent cardiovascular disease, diabetes, high blood pressure, and many other conditions. Eat the proper amount of nutritious food.

labelled_summary: Research indicates that individuals who engage in home-based exercise programs are more likely to adhere to their fitness routines due to the convenience and cost-effectiveness of exercising at home. The key components of physical fitness include aerobic endurance, crucial for combating cardiovascular disease through activities like walking, swimming, or cycling. Muscular endurance and strength, which contribute to a toned physique, can be achieved through resistance training using affordable equipment like barbells or dumbbells. Flexibility, important for preventing injuries, can be enhanced through practices such as yoga or effective stretching exercises. Maintaining a proper body weight is integral to overall health, as it helps prevent conditions like cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and high blood pressure. The accessibility and affordability of home-based exercise contribute to its effectiveness in promoting consistent physical activity.

question: Does anyone know what low voltage in the the frontal leads on a ECG means??
answers: It is probably normal, but it just means that yoyou have a lot of skin/fat tissue in front of your chest, e.g., if yoyou are fat. Another possible cause is hypothyroidism, but in that case, generally, there should be low voltage in all the leads and not just the frontal leads.
It means that the voltage in the frontal leads of the ECG are low.

The heart depends upon electrical impulses to beat sequentially. These impulses are picked up and read on an EKG. When there is a change in electrical impedence, remember Ohm's law, the voltage on the EKG is changed. Low voltage is most commonly caused by emphysema. Litterally normal QRS may be 7 - 10 mm, whereas with low voltage they are only 2 - 5 mm.
labelled_summary: For an EEG, low voltage in all leads, not just the frontal ones, is likely normal. In the context of an EKG, low voltage in the frontal leads indicates a change in electrical impedance, often associated with conditions like emphysema. In a normal EKG, QRS complexes may measure 7-10 mm, while in low voltage situations, they typically range from 2-5 mm. The heart relies on electrical impulses for sequential beating, and alterations in electrical impedance affect the EKG's recorded voltage.

question: if i have Chlamydia does my partner have to have it too?
answers: If yoyou test positive for chlamydia, your infection can be cured with antibiotics. Depending on several factors, your health care professional may prescribe azithromycin, in which case yoyou will take only a single dose, or yoyou may be prescribed doxycycline, which requires one pill twice a day for seven days. This may be followed by a test to see if yoyou are cured, but test of cure is not routine and is usually reserved for pregnant women or individuals with persisting or new symptoms. Penicillin is not considered as effective against chlamydia as azithromycin. If yoyou are pregnant and infected with chlamydia, yoyou still can be treated without harming the fetus. However, doxycycline is not recommended for pregnant women. The recommended regimen for pregnant women is erythromycin or amoxicillin for seven days, yet azithromycin as a single dose is also a possible option and recent studies and expert opinions suggest it is safe and effective. As with any antibiotic treatment, it is important that yoyou take all your pills, even after symptoms disappear. Because treatment with doxycycline or azithromycin is highly effective, women usually do not need retesting for chlamydia after treatment unless their symptoms persist or reinfection is suspected. Too often, women become reinfected because their partner has not been treated as well. Studies have shown that women who are reinfected with chlamydia have a much greater risk of developing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Therefore, it is important that yoyou abstain from sexual contact until your partner has been tested and completed treatment, meaning seven days after a single-dose azithromycin regimen or after completion of a seven-day doxycycline regimen. In general, treatment is recommended for any partner or partners yoyou had sexual contact with up to 60 days prior to having symptoms or a diagnosis of chlamydia. Some clinics are experimenting with what is called partner-delivered therapy. Patients are given a one-gram dose of azithromycin to give to their partner. There are legal and ethical debates about this approach but in some cases it may be the most effective way to stop the spread of chlamydia, because many infected male partners have no symptoms and are reluctant to seek treatment. Penicillin is not considered as effective against chlamydia as azithromycin or doxycycline. PID treatment begins with an antibiotic regimen that provides broad coverage against several different bacteria. Treatment should begin as soon as a diagnosis is made, because immediate therapy has been shown to reduce the risk of long-term consequences of PID. Studies are under way to determine whether oral therapy is as effective as parenteral (intravenous) therapy. There are several different treatment options recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Regardless of which type of therapy is chosen, hospitalization is no longer recommended, except in certain circumstances including: surgery is needed the patient is pregnant an oral outpatient regimen cannot be tolerated a patient does not respond clinically to oral antimicrobial therapy a patient has severe illness, including high fever, nausea and vomiting a patient has tubo-ovarian abscess or a weakened immune system While medication can stop PID, some women may need surgery to remove scar tissue and blockages caused by long-term infection. The most common type of surgery involves laparoscopy.

labelled_summary: If yoyou test positive for chlamydia, antibiotics can effectively cure the infection. Treatment may involve a single dose of azithromycin or a seven-day course of doxycycline, depending on various factors. Pregnant women are usually prescribed erythromycin or amoxicillin, although azithromycin is considered safe and effective. It is crucial to complete the full course of antibiotics, even if symptoms disappear. Women typically don't need retesting unless symptoms persist or reinfection is suspected. Partners should be treated to prevent reinfection, and partner-delivered therapy may be considered. Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) treatment involves antibiotics, with oral therapy being investigated as an alternative to intravenous treatment. Surgery may be necessary in some cases, especially if there are complications like tubo-ovarian abscess or extensive scar tissue. Overall, prompt and thorough treatment is essential to prevent long-term consequences of PID.

question: Does going out in the cold cause a cold?
answers: Hey here hope this helps, this is from the source, check out the full article. "scientists from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), a division of the National Institutes of Health, have shown that exposure to cold temperatures does not influence the development or severity of a cold. This means that if a person is exposed to a cold virus but isn't necessarily showing symptoms, exposure to cold temperature doesn't make a difference as to whether this person gets sick or how sick this person will become. Still, most colds occur during the fall and winter months, when schools begin to open and the mercury begins to fall. While cold temperatures do not cause colds, the colder months of the year seem to be more conducive to infection or transmission. This is probably due to many factors, including: >lower humidity >schools are in session >people spend more time indoors and in closer quarters >The cold season corresponds to the colder months of the year, which are also those with lower humidity. This absence of moisture may affect the number of infections as the most common cold-causing viruses thrive in lower humidity. What's more, dry air can dry the mucous lining of the nasal passages, making it more open to viral infection."

Going out into the cold weather has no effect on the spread of a cold. The reason that there appears to be a relationship is that people spend more time indoors during the cold winter weather. In fact, however, it is the proximity to other people rather than the temperature outside that seems to be the culprit. For this same reason, children in daycare or kindergarten are particularly prone to having colds.
NO! Weakened immune systems and germs cause colds
labelled_summary: Exposure to cold temperatures does not directly influence the development or severity of a cold, as demonstrated by scientists from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID). While cold temperatures themselves don't cause colds, most colds occur during fall and winter when schools open, and people spend more time indoors. Factors contributing to increased infections during colder months include lower humidity, schools being in session, and people spending more time in close quarters. The correlation between cold weather and colds is more related to human behavior, such as increased indoor proximity, rather than the temperature outside. Weakened immune systems and exposure to germs are primary factors in catching colds.

question: Is it normal to bruise easily when yoyou are taking blood thinners?

It is normal. Blood thinners disrupt the body's clotting mechanism, so even the smallest bumps - things yoyou may not realize happen, even rolling over in your sleep - can cause minor bruising. Of course excessive bruising could be a sign that your blood is too thin (e.g., yoyou may have a higher dose of anticoagulants than yoyou need). If you're doing this under a doctor's supervision, yoyou might ask him about it. If you're not, it's a good idea to speak with your physician just to be sure he's okay with this therapy.
labelled_summary: People with thin blood may experience easier bruising, which is a common side effect of taking blood thinners. Less common side effects of blood thinners include coughing up or vomiting blood, dark stools, skin rash, hives, itching, sore throat, hair loss, increased bruising, back pain, fever, chills, weakness, and yellowing of the skin or eyes (jaundice). While minor bruising is normal due to the disruption of the body's clotting mechanism by blood thinners, excessive bruising may indicate that the blood is too thin, possibly requiring an adjustment in the anticoagulant dosage.

question: Does your hair grow when you're in a coma?
answers: Yes, the hair, fingernails, and everything else that is supposed to grow, grows. The belief that a person's hair and fingernails grow after the person dies is false.
People who have been exhumed and demonstrated hair and fingernail growth were actually prematurely buried, awoke from their coma, and then died because they were unable to escape...
Yes , its almost the same thing its just it take coma's longer to wake up.
labelled_summary: Contrary to popular belief, hair and fingernails do not continue to grow after death. The misconception likely arises from observations during a coma when bodily functions, including hair and nail growth, may still occur. The idea that growth persists after death is debunked, as instances of exhumed individuals showing apparent hair and fingernail growth were likely cases of premature burial. In these instances, individuals initially thought to be deceased likely awoke from a coma, only to face dire consequences due to their inability to escape, leading to their eventual demise. Hair and nails continue to grow in a coma.

question: If I do not have high BP but Do have diabetes, why must I still be careful of sodium intake?
answers: Think about this one for a moment. Diabetes results when your body cannot use the glucose that is in your blood. The result is a high blood glucose concentration level in your blood. One of the ways yoyou can ease high blood sugar (along with insulin, of course) is to drink lots of water. If yoyou are well-hydrated, then there is not as much glucose in your blood relative to your overall blood volume. Sodium causes a restriction of the blood vessels; which in turn "thickens" the blood, and makes your blood glucose concentrations higher!

High blood pressure often goes hand in hand with Diabetes. I am sure your physician is limiting your sodium intake in order to cut down on your chances of developing medication-dependent hypertension at some point.
labelled_summary: For information purposes, diabetes occurs when the body is unable to effectively use the glucose in the blood, resulting in high blood glucose levels. Drinking ample water, in addition to insulin, can help alleviate high blood sugar by diluting the glucose concentration in the blood. Proper hydration reduces the relative amount of glucose in the blood compared to overall blood volume. The mention of sodium highlights its role in constricting blood vessels, thickening the blood, and contributing to elevated blood glucose concentrations. The association between diabetes and high blood pressure is noted, with a suggestion that physicians may limit sodium intake to reduce the risk of developing medication-dependent hypertension in individuals with diabetes.

question: Has anyone ever had "Ear Candling" done"?
answers: I tried eal candling a few years ago and worked very. I can hear better. It removed the excess wax from my ears. By the way it does not hurt.

Ear candles are a scam. The way it's described as working is pure bull. It's supposed to work by creating a gentle vacuum to pull out any wax in your ears. Yes, a flame will create a vacuum, but not if it's open to air. It needs to be enclosed. If yoyou enclose an ear candle, you'll end up popping your eardrum. Please try these experiments. Take a large sandwich bag and blow it up with your mouth so that it looks like a balloon. Now use your mouth to suck out all the air. That's what a collapsed bag looks like. Remember what it looks like. Now blow up the bag again. Put the small end of the candle into the bag's opening and light the candle. If it's supposed to create a vacuum effect, the plastic bag should completely collapse like when yoyou sucked out the air with your mouth. Do yoyou get the same effect? I didn't think so. As for removing excess wax from your ears, the stuff yoyou see at the bottom of the candle is not ear wax. It's just the ash from the candle. If yoyou don't believe me, try candling your ear and see how much material comes out. Next, put one of those ear candles into a cup and burn it. You'll notice that the same amount of material will show up at the bottom of the candle. Are yoyou telling me that the candle pulled ear wax out of a cup? The candles work through a psychosomatic effect. It's similar to someone taking a sugar pill and actually feeling better because they believe it. I suppose the heat would also make your ears feel better, but it's not a real solution if yoyou have an ear infection or other disease. Don't waste your money. If your ear hurts, see a doctor. It could be an ear infection. If yoyou have excess wax, go to your local pharmacy and pick up some ear wax removal drops.

question: What are the odds of getting pregnant while on the Depo shot?
answers: It is 97-99.7% effective so chances are pretty low

Yoyou asked what are your chances. Each woman's fertility is unique. It may take time for fertility to return after using depo provera or any hormonal birth control. If yoyou want to get pregnant, it may take some time for your cycles to go back to "normal." However, if yoyou do not want to get pregnant, the best thing to do is use another form of birth control. Yoyou may become fertile any time after 12 weeks after your most recent depo shot. No one can tell yoyou when. Remember that your period starts 2 weeks (14 days) after the ovaries release an egg. There is no way to know in advance when ovulation will happen for sure. Because sperm can stay alive inside the woman's body for up to 7 days, pregnancy can happen fairly easily. The shot itself is over 99 percent effective in preventing pregnancy during its estimated three month period. If yoyou don't get your period by 16 weeks since your last depo shot, and yoyou have had unprotected sex, yoyou may want a pregnancy test. Yoyou can get an over the counter pregnancy test at any drug store. They are quite reliable. There are also several clinics that offer free pregnancy tests. Best, `k.
If yoyou are getting your Depo injections when yoyou are supposed to then yoyou will not get pregnant.Depo is highly effective.
labelled_summary: For information purposes, the Depo shot is highly effective, with a 97-99.7% success rate in preventing pregnancy. However, it's important to note that each woman's fertility is unique, and it may take some time for fertility to return after discontinuing Depo or any hormonal birth control. While yoyou can become fertile anytime after 12 weeks from your last Depo shot, it's challenging to predict exactly when. Since sperm can survive inside the body for up to 7 days, pregnancy can occur relatively easily if unprotected sex takes place. If yoyou haven't had your period by 16 weeks after your last Depo shot and have had unprotected intercourse, consider taking a reliable over-the-counter pregnancy test or seek one at a clinic.

question: Why do I wake up with an erection?
answers: It is a normal part of the REM period of sleep for a man to have an erection. Yoyou will have up to 5 cycles of all of your sleep stages (I, II, III, IV, and REM). While your dreaming in REM, your bodies muscle are all paralyzed (so yoyou don't act your dreams out), this includes those that allow blood flow for an erection. The early part of your night will have short REM periods, but they get longer as the night goes on. Most people will be in close proximity to a very long REM period when they wake up in the morning...thus with an erection. On a side note, an old school method to test for physiological vs psychological impotence was to wrap and secure the penis with several stamps on a roll before bed. In the course of the night, if a man was physiologically able to maintain an erection he would do so during REM sleep and break the perferations on the stamp roll. In the morning yoyou had a diagnosis.

It's normal to get one roughly 3 times every night if yoyou sleep a full 8 hours. That tissue is among the most poorly oxygenated in the body, and some believe that this is why erections are part of a regular sleep cycle. That being said, impotent men who cannot get an erection do not wake up with the thing having fallen off due to lack of oxygen in the tissues :)

During the REM cycle, the muscles of the body are paralysed including the muscles that control the flow of blood to the penis. In the early part of the night, the REM periods are shorter, but they get longer as the night progresses. Most people are in close proximity to a very long REM period when they wake up in the morning with an erection. Additionally, the penis tissue is among the most poorly oxygenated in the body, hence according to some, it is believed that causes the erection. However it shouldn't be concluded that men who cannot get an erection, do not wake up with the no erections due to lack of oxygen in the tissues.

question: Is there a way to make my voice deeper?
answers: Yoyou can modify your technique of speaking to include a deeper tone. Most people speak from the front of their mouth, where the tone created is not deep. Try speaking from the back of your throat and yoyou will instantly have more resonance and a deeper and fuller tone. Also, practice diaphramatic breathing rather than "shoulder breathing". When yoyou inhale, your diaphram muscles should tense slightly, and release tension as yoyou expell air. Developing the diaphram muscles will improve your tone by allowing yoyou to control the metering of your air.
labelled_summary: It is suggested that yoyou can enhance the depth and resonance of your speaking voice by adjusting your technique. Instead of speaking from the front of your mouth, try speaking from the back of your throat for a deeper and fuller tone. Additionally, practicing diaphragmatic breathing, as opposed to "shoulder breathing," can contribute to a more controlled and resonant voice. When yoyou inhale, engage your diaphragm muscles, allowing them to tense slightly, and release tension as yoyou exhale. Strengthening your diaphragm muscles through regular practice can improve your voice quality and help yoyou better regulate the rhythm of your speech.

question: Can i transfer hpv to another person?
answers: Fifth's disease, or erythema infectiosa, has been recognized much more in the past few years. We now know that it is caused by the human parvo virus B19-3. It is called Fifth's disease after four more common viral rash illnesses seen in children which are measles, scarlet fever, rubella and scarlatina. The Sixth's disease is roseola. Fifth's disease virus, or human parvo virus B19, is attracted to rapidly dividing cells in the body. Therefore people with weak immune systems and with weak red blood cells are at high risk. This includes people with sickle cell disease, hereditary spirochaetosis, any serious immune disease or cancer, and AIDS. It also might include someone with recurrent blood loss and anemia. In these patients, a very severe with profound anemia and a very severe disease without the typical rash. These patients obviously need the care of an experienced physician and frequently a hematologist. For the majority of patients, however, Fifths disease is a mild viral infection which starts with typical cold like symptoms in adults and sometimes vague muscle aches and headache. This is the time in which the patient is actually contagious and the virus is multiplying in the body. After a few days, the virus clears and antibodies to the virus cause a classic rash in the skin. In adults, there is usually some joint swelling and tenderness. In children the rash is a slightly raised, bright red patch over the facial cheeks with some clearing directly around the mouth. Also present is a lacy pink to red rash scattered over the extremities and trunk. Usually palms and soles are spared. About 50% of the time, the rash itches. The rash seems to fade and come back whenever the child is stressed or exposed to a lot of sun or overheating. In older adolescents and adults, the rash may not appear as the typical rash seen in children. The predominant symptoms seen in up to 60% of adults is joint swelling usually the wrist, hands or ankles. This may last for up to a few weeks but does not cause any permanent changes and does not cause rheumatoid arthritis. The joint symptoms are only found in about 3% of children up to age nine. Again, most children will acquire Fifth's disease at some time in their life and most adults, when tested for antibodies show evidence of having had it sometime in their life. The risk to a pregnant woman is considered about .6% and should be taken into account since a growing fetus does have both a weak immune system and rapidly dividing red cells and is, therefore, susceptible to the virus. It is not recommended that children with Fifth's disease be excluded from school because by the time the rash appears, they are actually not contagious. It is also not recommended that pregnant women be excluded from day care or other work situations because of the relative low risk to them. They should be aware, however, of any epidemics taking place and use good hand washing as a means of decreasing the spread of the virus. There is presently no vaccine but there is some experimental evidence that IV gamma globulin may help in high risk patients; however it is not presently recommended for routine patients. Infants of mothers who contract parvo virus B19 in early pregnancy are at risk for severe blood loss but do not develop birth defects. In cases where the diagnosis is picked up there have been fetal blood exchanges done and the infants have been saved through this procedure. Obviously this is something that would require a sophisticated medical center and a team of perinatologists and obstetrician.
yes yoyou can but only if your infected skin touches someone else's skin
labelled_summary: Fifth's disease, or erythema infectiosum, is caused by human parvovirus B19-3. Named after its place among common viral rash illnesses in children, it is characterized by cold-like symptoms, muscle aches, and headache during the contagious phase. The classic rash in children appears as a bright red patch on the facial cheeks, with a lacy pink to red rash on extremities and trunk. About 50% of the time, the rash itches. Adults may experience joint swelling, typically in the wrists, hands, or ankles. While most cases are mild, pregnant women face a risk of about 0.6%. There is no vaccine, and though IV gamma globulin is being studied, it is not recommended for routine patients. Pregnant women are advised to practice good hand hygiene during outbreaks. If infected skin touches someone else's skin, transmission is possible.

question: what is proteolytic enzyme tablets?
answers: I assume yoyou are talking about something like Pancrease which is a pill that contains the normal proteolytic enzymes that are released by your pancreas to aid in digestion. They cleave bonds in protein to make more simple molecules that your intestines can absorb and are usually prescribed for people that have inadequate pancreas function.

Proteases (proteinases, peptidases or proteolytic enzymes) are enzymes that break peptide bonds between amino acids of proteins. The process is called proteolytic cleavage, a common mechanism of activation or inactivation of enzymes especially involved in blood coagulation or digestion. They use a molecule of water for this and are thus classified as hydrolases. Classification There are currently six classes of proteases: Serine proteases Threonine proteases Cysteine proteases Aspartic acid proteases (e. g. plasmepsin) Metalloproteases Glutamic acid proteases The threonine and glutamic peptidases were not described until 1995 and 2004, respectively. The mechanism used to cleave a peptide bond involves making an amino acid residue (serine, cystein and threonine peptidases) or a water molecule (aspartic, metallo and glutamic peptidases) nucleophilic so that it can attack the peptide carbonyl group. One way to make a nucleophile is by a catalytic triad, where a histidine residue is used to activate serine, cysteine or threonine as a nucleophile. Occurrence Proteases occur naturally in all organisms and constitute 1-5% of the gene content. These enzymes are involved in a multitude of physiological reactions from simple digestion of food proteins to highly regulated cascades (e.g. the blood clotting cascade, the complement system and the invertebrate prophenoloxidase activating cascade). Peptidases can break either specific peptide bonds (limited proteolysis), depending on the amino acid sequence of a protein, or break down a complete peptide to amino acids (unlimited proteolysis). The activity can be a destructive change abolishing a protein's function or digesting it to its principal components, it can be an activation of a function or it can be a signal in a signalling pathway.
labelled_summary: Pancrease, contains the normal proteolytic enzymes enzymes similar to those released by the pancreas for digestion. These enzymes, called proteases, break peptide bonds in proteins through a process known as proteolytic cleavage. Pancrease is typically prescribed for individuals with insufficient pancreatic function. Proteases belong to six classes, including serine, threonine, cysteine, aspartic acid, metallo, and glutamic acid proteases. These enzymes play crucial roles in various physiological reactions, from food protein digestion to regulated cascades like blood clotting and immune responses. The mechanism of peptide bond cleavage involves creating a nucleophile, often through a catalytic triad. Proteases are naturally occurring and participate in essential biological processes, either breaking specific peptide bonds or completely breaking down peptides into amino acids.

question: what does labatelol do?
answers: What is labetalol? Labetalol is in a class of drugs called beta-blockers. Beta-blockers affect the heart and circulatory system (arteries and veins). Labetalol is used to treat hypertension (high blood pressure). Labetalol may also be used for purposes other than those listed in Before taking labetalol, tell your doctor if yoyou have asthma; a heart problem such as low blood pressure, a slow heart rate, heart block, sick sinus syndrome, a pacemaker, heart failure, and others; diabetes; depression; thyroid disease; kidney disease; liver disease; or any type of circulatory disease. Yoyou may not be able to take labetalol, or yoyou may require a dosage adjustment or special monitoring during treatment if yoyou have any of the conditions listed above.

labelled_summary: Labetalol belongs to a class of drugs known as beta-blockers, impacting the heart and circulatory system, including arteries and veins. Primarily used to treat hypertension (high blood pressure), labetalol may also serve other purposes not listed in official medical guidelines. Before using labetalol, it's crucial to inform your doctor about various health conditions, including asthma, heart problems (such as low blood pressure, slow heart rate, heart block, sick sinus syndrome, pacemaker, heart failure), diabetes, depression, thyroid disease, kidney disease, liver disease, or any circulatory issues. Depending on your medical history, your doctor may need to adjust the dosage or closely monitor your condition during labetalol treatment.

labelled_summary: For information purposes, the HIV virus cannot survive in the air, and it cannot be transmitted through casual contact, such as sharing a glass. The virus is primarily transmitted through direct blood-to-blood contact or through sexual intercourse. While there is a theoretical risk if the person sharing the glass had an open sore in their mouth and the saliva came into contact with blood, the likelihood of HIV transmission in such scenarios is extremely low. It's important to note that HIV is not transmitted through activities like sharing utensils, using public toilets, or through tears, sweat, and saliva under normal circumstances. Precautions should be taken to prevent direct blood contact to minimize the risk of HIV transmission.

PREVENTING CRISIS Parents whose children have sickle cell should encourage their children to lead normal lives. However, in order to decrease the occurrence of sickle cell crises, consider the following precautions: To prevent tissue deoxygenation, avoid the following: Strenuous physical activity, especially if the spleen is enlarged Emotional stress Environments with low oxygen content (high altitudes, non-pressurized airplane flights) Known sources of infection To promote proper hydration: Recognize signs of dehydration Avoid excess exposure to the sun Provide access to fluids, both at home and away To avoid sources of infection: Keep child properly immunized as recommended by the health care provider Consider having the child wear a Medic Alert Bracelet Share above information with teachers and other caretakers as appropriate Be aware of the effects that chronic, life-threatening illnesses can have on siblings, marital relationships, parents, and the child

question: What are the chances and life span of 1 who is strciken with non-small cell lung cancer? Honestly, its my mom.
answers: Well, I'm not going to 'sugar coat' this. Sadly: "For most patients with non-small cell lung cancer, current treatments do not cure the cancer." "Lung cancer is highly lethal, with the highest recorded 5-year patient survival rates (14%) observed in the United States. In Europe, the 5-year overall survival rate is 8%, similar to that of the developing world." I would research clinical trials and try to get her to be allowed to participate in such trials. My best, David //

Yoyou should talk to the doctors dealing with your mother; they can give yoyou a better assessment than anyone here can, since they know all the details of the case. It really depends on the exact case - there's a lot they can do, but there are also cases where they can't do much. As a rough guide, the better the general condition of the patient, the more they can do - many cancer treatments require an otherwise fairly healthy patient to be really effective. Additionally, the earlier they've caught the cancer, the better the chances they'll be able to remove it successfully. If things go well, and the cancer can be dealt with successfully, your mom can have a normal lifespan - but talk to the doctors to get an assessment of how things are in this particular case. Hope things go well; I've gone through something similar with my dad, and yoyou have my sympathy.
labelled_summary: It's advisable to consult with healthcare professionals who can provide a more accurate assessment of the specific case, given their knowledge of all the details. The effectiveness of treatments for lung cancer depends on the exact case, with the patient's overall health playing a significant role. Generally, better overall health and early detection enhance the prospects of successful cancer removal. If the cancer can be effectively dealt with, the individual may have a normal lifespan. Unfortunately, current treatments for non-small cell lung cancer typically do not cure the disease, and survival rates are relatively low. Exploring participation in clinical trials could be a research avenue to pursue for potential alternative treatments.

question: hip dysplasia in infants?
answers: I was born with this. Your Pediatrician should check for it. If yoyou have suspicious, have your Ped check NOW. There are great measures to reduce the problems throughout life. I actually spent 17 years in ballet with HP in both hips. I still have a "clunk" in my left hip, which may cause issues later in life, but now, in my 30's I have no major issues. Check now!

The most common scenario is the pediatrician detecting a "hip click" during routine post-natal checkup. Actually, a "clunk", rather than a "click" is detected in the unstable hip, but it requires experience to tell a "clunk" from a "click". The pediatrician typically does the Ortolani test by spreading the thighs, or the Barlow test by bringing the knees together, to elicit this finding. In the older infant, the pediatrician may suspect the problem if the child has tight hip adductors - he has a hard time spreading the baby’s hips. He may also notice that the skin creases around the groin or the buttocks are not symmetrical. Or the legs may appear to be of different lengths. At age one, the affected child may present with a limp. Unfortunately, pain is not a problem in the child, hence it is easy to miss the diagnosis. However, by the time the patient becomes an adult, arthritic changes will occur, and pain will set in.

when the hip is dislocated at birth or becomes dislocated through various reasons(such as from stress).It happens in about 4 to 1000 births.Frequently occurs in the Lapps and American Indian races.Commonly among first borns and girls.It is a malformation of the hip and genetic features play a huge role in it.It usually happens when babies are born in a breech position (especially with feet up by shoulders).It could be due to swaddling and using cradleboards for restraining infants.

My daughter had it from a bad delivery. 26 hours grr. It IS painful! She screamed and screamed and no one knew why. Out the doot to take her home, they spread her legs for the hip test and sure enough they were dislocated. As soon as she got her brace on she stopped screaming and was no longer in pain! SHe had to wear it for 3 months which gave the hips time to heal. She is 100% normal now at 16
labelled_summary: For information purposes, the most common scenario for detecting developmental hip dysplasia is during a pediatrician's routine post-natal checkup, where a "clunk" may be noticed during tests like the Ortolani or Barlow test. Signs in older infants may include tight hip adductors or asymmetrical skin creases around the groin or buttocks. By age one, the child may present with a limp, though pain is not typically a symptom. If untreated, arthritic changes may occur in adulthood, leading to pain. Hip dysplasia is more prevalent in certain populations, such as the Lapps and American Indian races, and is more common in first-borns and girls. Genetic factors play a significant role, and breech births, especially with feet up by the shoulders, may contribute. Swaddling and using cradleboards for restraining infants could also be associated with hip dysplasia, occurring in approximately 4 out of 1000 births.

question: can stress kill you?
answers: How much stress and of what kind? Heat stress as well as extreme cold can kill. Emotional stress can lower the immune system leading to illness and possibly death. On the other hand a little stress is good for you. Exercise is a form of stress that keeps yoyou fit. Mental stress (Will I fail?) may inspire yoyou to study hard and survive the test. Stress often involves the human fight and flight reaction, releasing lots of adrenalin (ever feel the hairs on your neck rise - perhaps a barking dog right behind you? in a dark alley?). Ancient man had to tackle a different set of problems than we do today. Do I stand and fight the saber-toothed tiger or flee? Adrenalin helped with either decision (but not much with the tiger battle). A great deal of activity, kicking or running, then burned off the excess adrenalin. Today, when we get angry say at a red traffic light, we build up the adrenalin but just sit there and steem without burning it off. And that can harm the cardiovascular system (which includes the heart). Yoyou have a choice. Either sit there shaking your fist fuming at a tiny red light filament and destroy your otherwise perfect body - or - say "I've been good and I deserve this 90 second break," taking your whitened fists off the steering wheel while relaxing and breething deeply. Either way, it's your heart. Good luck.
Not only can stress kill you, it happens enough that the Japanese actually have a name for it: "karoshi" which is "death from overwork".

Yes ... stress is a mentally or emotionally disruptive or upsetting condition occurring in response to adverse external influences and capable of affecting physical health, usually characterized by increased heart rate, a rise in blood pressure, muscular tension, irritability, and depression.

labelled_summary: For information purposes, stress, whether physical, emotional, or environmental, can have significant impacts on health. While moderate stress can be a motivating factor, excessive and chronic stress has been linked to various health issues, including cardiovascular problems, high blood pressure, and a weakened immune system. The body's fight-or-flight response, triggered by stress, releases adrenaline and can lead to physical manifestations like increased heart rate, elevated blood pressure, muscle tension, irritability, and even depression. It is crucial to manage stress levels through healthy coping mechanisms, as chronic stress has been associated with adverse health outcomes. The Japanese term "karoshi," meaning "death from overwork," highlights the severity of extreme stress on health. Learning effective stress management techniques is essential for maintaining overall well-being and preventing potential health risks.

question: Does your heart really stop when yoyou sneeze?

Check your pulse next time to prove this to yourself.

question: What is Down Syndrome'?
answers: Down syndrome n. A congenital disorder, caused by the presence of an extra 21st chromosome, in which the affected person has mild to moderate mental retardation, short stature, and a flattened facial profile. Also called trisomy 21. Down syndrome (also known as Down's syndrome) encompasses a number of genetic disorders, of which trisomy 21 (a nondisjunction) is the most representative, causing highly variable degrees of learning difficulties as well as physical disabilities. It is named for John Langdon Down, the British doctor who first described it in the late 19th century.

labelled_summary: For information purposes, down syndrome, also referred to as trisomy 21, is a congenital disorder caused by the presence of an extra 21st chromosome. This genetic condition, named after the British doctor John Langdon Down, manifests with mild to moderate mental retardation, short stature, and a flattened facial profile. It encompasses various genetic disorders, with trisomy 21 being the most representative form, leading to variable degrees of learning difficulties and physical disabilities. The syndrome is characterized by slowed growth, abnormal facial features, and mental retardation due to the additional chromosome 21. The incidence of Down syndrome is estimated at 1 per 800 births, making it the most common chromosomal abnormality. Although individuals with Down syndrome may exhibit distinct physical features and experience slowed growth, they can often speak understandably, despite being hyperactive. It is essential to approach Down syndrome with sensitivity, as it is not a disease but rather a birth defect. Life expectancy is typically shortened, with many affected individuals not living past age 30. It is crucial to use appropriate terminology, such as "Down syndrome," and refrain from making derogatory comments that may contribute to stigmatization.

question: What are the side effects of Vicodin?
answers: For starters Drowsyness ok here we go SIDE EFFECTS: Nausea, vomiting, constipation, lightheadedness, dizziness, drowsiness, flushing, vision changes, or mental/mood changes may occur. If any of these effects persist or worsen, notify your doctor or pharmacist promptly. Tell your doctor immediately if any of these unlikely but serious side effects occur: slow/irregular breathing, slow/irregular heartbeat, change in the amount of urine. Tell your doctor immediately if any of these highly unlikely but very serious side effects occur: impairment or loss of hearing (especially with high doses for long periods). If yoyou do not have liver problems, the adult maximum dose of acetaminophen is 4 grams per day (4000 milligrams). If yoyou take more than the maximum daily amount, it may cause serious (possibly fatal) liver disease. Tell your doctor immediately if yoyou have any of the following symptoms of liver damage: severe nausea, yellowing eyes or skin, dark urine, stomach pain, extreme fatigue. An allergic reaction to this drug is unlikely, but seek immediate medical attention if it occurs. Symptoms of an allergic reaction include: rash, itching, swelling, severe dizziness, trouble breathing. If yoyou notice other effects not listed above, contact your doctor or pharmacist http://www.medicinenet.com/hydrocodoneacetaminophen-oral/article.htm section juss for side effects

labelled_summary: For information purposes, the diagnosis of meningitis involves several key steps. A physical examination is conducted to assess symptoms and signs of infection. Blood tests are performed to identify any abnormalities or signs of inflammation. To confirm the diagnosis definitively, a lumbar puncture, also known as a spinal tap, is typically conducted. This procedure involves extracting a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal canal to analyze for the presence of infection, such as bacteria. Additionally, in cases of tuberculous meningitis, fundoscopy and specific tests for tuberculous bacilli in the cerebrospinal fluid are recommended. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) based identification of the bacteria can also be utilized for accurate diagnosis. While a lumbar puncture can be uncomfortable, it is considered a crucial diagnostic tool for meningitis when needed.

question: WHAT IS THE FEELING OF RAPID HEART BEAT?

labelled_summary: Tachycardia refers to an unusually fast heart rate, and the sensation of a rapid heartbeat is known as palpitations. Individuals may be aware of their own heartbeat, feel skipped or stopped beats, and these sensations can occur in the chest, throat, or neck. The heart's rhythm during palpitations can be either normal or abnormal.

question: Does a boy molested as a child always grow up to be a predator?

On the other hand, young children who are sexually abused (whether they're male or female) will often act out "mimic" what's been done to them onto others if they don't get help...not all victims...but some! But this is more "sexually reactive" behaviors...they are reactive to what's happened to them versus being "predators" or an "offender" in the true sense of the word. Most importantly, with early interventions with a therapist who has EXPERIENCE working with children who've been sexually abused...all children, male or female, can become SURVIVORS who will live happy, healthy, productive lives. In my experience and understanding, boys who've been molested actually rarely grow up to be a "predators"! They more often have difficulties in their own relationships with domestic violence, sexual dysfunction, substance abuse problems, etc.. Bottom line.........the young boy needs therapy to heal from his experience as soon as possible!

question: what is good to take for sore knees?
answers: Glucosamine and Chondroitin Sulfate: Glucosamine and Chondroitin Sulfate What are Glucosamine and Chondroitin Sulfate? What Do They Do? What Do I Look For? How Do I Take Them? Are There Side Effects? Cautions What are Glucosamine and Chondroitin Sulfate? Glucosamine and chondroitin sulfate are substances found naturally in the body. Glucosamine is a form of amino sugar that is believed to play a role in cartilage formation and repair. Chondroitin sulfate is part of a large protein molecule (proteoglycan) that gives cartilage elasticity. Both glucosamine and chondroitin sulfate are sold as dietary or nutritional supplements. They are extracted from animal tissue: glucosamine from crab, lobster or shrimp shells; and chondroitin sulfate from animal cartilage, such as tracheas or shark cartilage. What do they do? Past studies show that some people with mild to moderate osteoarthritis (OA) taking either glucosamine or chondroitin sulfate reported pain relief at a level similar to that of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as aspirin and ibuprofen. Some research indicates that the supplements might also slow cartilage damage in people with OA. Definitive results about the effects of these supplements are expected from an in-depth clinical study currently being conducted by the National Institutes of Health.
labelled_summary: For information purposes, glucosamine and chondroitin sulfate, naturally occurring substances in the body, are believed to play roles in cartilage formation and elasticity. Derived from sources like crab shells and animal cartilage, these compounds are available as dietary supplements. Studies suggest that individuals with mild to moderate osteoarthritis (OA) may experience pain relief comparable to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like aspirin and ibuprofen. Some research indicates a potential for slowing cartilage damage in OA patients. Ongoing clinical studies by the National Institutes of Health aim to provide more definitive insights into the effects of these supplements. When considering their use, it's advisable to consult with healthcare professionals to assess individual needs and potential side effects.

question: What's connected to the other side of your belly button?
answers: just inside your belly button is a ligament that attaches near your bladder. This was originally a bundle of blood vessels passing through the umbilicus (umbilical cord); after birth these blood vessels, being no longer necessary, close up to form a ligament.
WOW! These guys are smart!

during fetal development, the abdominal organs form around the umbilical cord. at the end of the first, beginning of the second trimester, the cord snaps into the abdomen pulling these organs into correct anatomical order and muscle and skin form over the abdomen. after birth, the umbilical cord dries out, falls out, and the remainder inside the body becomes a ligament that attaches into the abdominal muscles. the belly button has no function after gestation, but they look nice don't they?
labelled_summary: For information purposes, during fetal development, abdominal organs form around the umbilical cord. Towards the end of the first and beginning of the second trimester, the umbilical cord snaps into the abdomen, arranging the organs in their correct anatomical order. Subsequently, muscle and skin develop over the abdomen. After birth, the umbilical cord dries out, falls off, and the remaining portion inside the body transforms into a ligament, attaching to the abdominal muscles. The belly button serves no function post-gestation. Just inside it is a ligament that attaches near the bladder, originally a bundle of blood vessels passing through the umbilicus. After birth, these vessels close up, forming a ligament.

question: Why does a specific treatment for a diseased condition work for one person and not another?
answers: Our micro biology minor gave the best answer...I would like to add that the same disease may present itself differently in people. Also, the general health and lifestyle of a person may be a major factor in treatment. If a person has a chronic disease such as diabetes, or has allergies to certain antibiotics, or has cancer, a series of different treatments for their chronic disease may be needed over time, or if a secondary disease to the chronic disease is a problem, may need a different treatment than a healthy person would need. Just as people have subtle differences....so too diseases....There are some staph bacteria resistant to antibiotics....some staph bacteria respond very well to antibiotics. The same but different.

Although everyone has 99.999% of their DNA in common, there are subtile differences. These differences become apparent when a treatment is used to alter a specific protein or process in the body. If the protein being altered is fundementally different in my body compared to the majority of other people, then that treatment will not work on me the way it would on everyone else.
everyone is diffrent that is why there are so many diffrent drugs for the same problem.
labelled_summary: In the realm of microbiology, it's important to understand that the same disease can manifest differently in people. Factors like a person's overall health and lifestyle play a significant role in treatment. Chronic conditions, allergies, or other health issues can require unique treatments. Just as people have subtle genetic differences, diseases also exhibit variations. Even though most of our DNA is the same, there are subtle distinctions that matter when we try to modify specific proteins or processes in the body. If these proteins differ fundamentally from person to person, a treatment that works for most might not work the same way for someone with unique genetic characteristics. Variability among individuals is why there are numerous drugs for the same medical conditions.

Don't Drink the Diet Coke Perhaps a friend has forwarded yoyou an email from "Nancy Markle," which sets out to document the dangers of the artificial sweetener, aspartame, manufactured by Monsanto. Aspartame is the basis of NutraSweet and Equal, flavors Diet Coke, Diet Pepsi, and other drinks, and sweetens a host of foods yoyou or I wouldn’t even begin to suspect. The email, together with a number of websites, credits the artificial sweetener with nearly every woe known to humankind, from MS to Gulf War syndrome. In the words of the letter: "If yoyou are using aspartame ... and yoyou suffer from fibromyalgia symptoms, spasms, shooting pains, numbness in your legs, cramps, vertigo, dizziness, headaches, tinnitus, joint pain, depression, anxiety attacks, slurred speech, blurred vision, or memory loss - yoyou probably have aspartame disease." "Yoyou probably have aspartame disease" is a gross overstatement, but so is the term "urban legend" loosely bandied about in various pro-aspartame articles on a number of websites, at least one industry-sponsored. The scientific evidence may fall well short of pinning an actual rap on the sweetener, but it is sufficient enough to raise a legitimate concern. What We Know About Aspartame Three byproducts of aspartame are methanol, formaldehyde, and formate, which defenders maintain occur in modest amounts - similar to what is found in fruit juices - and cannot be considered toxic. But according to Michael Schachter MD in an article on HealthWorld, the methanol in juices is chemically bound so it cannot be absorbed into the body whereas in aspartame it is in a free state where it can be absorbed. Additionally, in aspartame the methanol is unaccompanied by ethanol which acts as a protectant in its natural state. A Medline search reveals divided opinion over whether aspartame consumption can lead to worrisome build-ups of blood methanol or formaldehyde. A 1998 Spanish study on rats, for example, warns "that aspartame consumption may constitute a hazard because of its contribution to the formation of formaldehyde adducts," while a 2002 Japanese study on rats concludes: "It is suggested that aspartame at abuse doses is harmless to humans." A survey of aspartame studies by Ralph Walton MD of Northeastern Ohio Universities College of Medicine found: "Of the 166 studies felt to have relevance for questions of human safety, 74 had NutraSweet industry related funding and 92 were independently funded. One hundred percent of the industry funded research attested to aspartame's safety, whereas 92 percent of the independently funded research identified a problem." One in 15,000 people may not properly metabolize phenylalanine, an essential amino acid found in aspartame. The substance is a precursor to tyrosine, a building block of norepinephrine and dopamine, but, in the words of the FDA: "High levels of this amino acid in body fluids can cause brain damage." Accordingly, the FDA duly requires a warning that all products containing the sweetener be labeled for the substance. Newborns are routinely screened for phenylalanine metabolism (the PKU test), which rules out the likelihood of an unsuspecting consumer gulping down hemlock. The FDA approved aspartame for use in certain dry foods in 1981 and for soft drinks in 1983. In 1996, it removed all restrictions, allowing use in all food products, including ones exposed to heat, which separates the main ingredients. The FDA has set an acceptable daily limit of 50 mg per kg of body weight, which assumes that aspartame can safely replace all sucrose sweeteners in the diet. The FDA approval, however, should not be equated with safety, particularly in light of how the product got the green light. In 1980 a three-member board of inquiry examined the test results of Searle, the pharmaceutical arm of Monsanto that manufactures aspartame. Although they thought
It shouldn't cause any serious health problems, though carbonated beverages have a negative effect on bone mass and weaken the enamel of the teeth.
labelled_summary: For information purposes, diet Coke, along with other artificially sweetened products like NutraSweet and Equal, relies on the artificial sweetener aspartame, manufactured by Monsanto. The text explores concerns surrounding aspartame, as raised in an email and various websites, which attribute a range of health issues to its consumption, from fibromyalgia symptoms to depression. The discussion delves into the byproducts of aspartame, such as methanol, formaldehyde, and formate, with divided opinions on their potential toxicity. The text highlights the controversy in scientific studies, noting the influence of industry funding on research outcomes. It also touches on the issue of phenylalanine metabolism and the FDA's mandated warnings. Despite FDA approval, the text cautions against equating approval with safety, particularly given the circumstances of the approval process. Lastly, it briefly mentions the potential negative effects of carbonated beverages like Diet Coke on bone mass and tooth enamel.

question: How much should a root canal and crown cost (molar)?
answers: That question is highly variable, depending on where yoyou live..(ie, urban vs rural, US vs other countries) and the cost of the laboratory your dentist will be using to construct the crown. Endodontists are dental specialists that have additional graduate training, and they specialize in root canals, and other advanced therapies that can be life saving to a tooth. They tend to have much better success rates in treatment outcomes, but also tend to be more expensive ( in an urban area, as much as 900$ to 1,200$ for an upper molar). General dentists may charge less, but may also be more likely to fracture or fail the attempted proceedure, which may result in tooth loss. Failure is possible, in any event, namely because a root canal is indicated when a vital tooth is quite sick, anyway. Crown costs are dependent on quality of the material (gold or porcelaine), the quality or fee charged by the lab the dentist chooses, and how much profit the dentist chooses to make off the proceedure. I have heard of fees as low as 400$ for stainless steel 'shells' in US rural areas (bad idea..), or prices as high as $2,000 per crown, if by high profile dentists in urban practices. An average estimate in an urban area in the US might be 800-1000$ for a full coverage, noble metal crown. A good way to find a good honest general dentist, is to call several local "Periodontists". They are specialists that see the best, and worst of general dentistry.
labelled_summary: For information purposes, the cost of dental procedures, such as crowns and root canals, varies based on factors like location and the type of dentist. Endodontists, specialized in root canals, often have higher success rates but may be more expensive. General dentists may charge less but could have higher failure rates. Crown costs depend on material quality, lab fees, and dentist profit margins. Prices range from $400 for basic crowns in rural areas to $2,000 for high-profile urban practices. To find a reliable general dentist, seeking recommendations from periodontists, who witness various dental outcomes, can be beneficial.
